The activity that Olga engages in is raising free-range chickens.  To do this, she has a small shed with a maximum capacity of 150 chickens, which is set up on the second floor of her house.  There she raises them and sells them in the market, succeeding in selling her entire production.  She also sells fast food at night in front of her house.

She started a year ago with her own capital, fruits of her savings, and the support of her son for cleaning and feeding the chickens in his spare time.  She considers the business quite profitable for the demand that this product has, since it is heavily consumed in the daily diet of the population.  She likes this activity since it gives her extra economic income for the household expenses, and also because it helps her feel like a productive woman and pass the time.  On the other hand, what she does not like about this activity is that sometimes part of her production has died due to pestilence, causing some losses.  She has been able to start over thanks to the support of MFP, which is why she has plans to continue with this activity, make some repairs and build a small shed on the first floor of her house, with capacity for 200 chickens.

This is her fifth loan with MFP, and she counts on their support to be able to carry out her plans.  On the other hand, she says that she will make her repayments, so that she has a good credit record.  Additionally, she is very happy with her community bank, and considers them friendly and supportive people.

With the amount she has requested of 1500 nuevos soles, she will invest in repairing the infrastructure of her shed, buying corrugated iron to renovate the roof and chips for the floor for the baby chicks to begin with a new production of at least 150 chickens.

loans.use: to buy corrugated iron to renovate the roof, chips for the floor of the chicken house, and thus start with a new production of at least 150 chickens.

loans.name: Tania

texts.es:
Tania, de 42 años de edad  es una mujer trabajadora y entusiasta, además de alegre y amable, está separada de su pareja, vive en compañía de madre y sus 03 hijos de 14, 09 y 03 años de edad, instalados cómodamente en su casa propia. El negocio que tiene Tania es la venta de golosinas en un tablero que instala en el frontis de su casa todos los días, iniciándose con un préstamo particular hace  3 años, logrando ganarse el aprecio y la preferencia de sus clientes que en su mayoría son sus vecinos gracias a su buena atención y manera amable de tratar,  además de contar con la ayuda de su madre para atender a los clientes.
Le gusta su negocio pues le genera un ingreso económico adicional así como le permite socializar con su vecinos, además comenta que le permite tener  una ocupación y sentirse productiva ya que cuenta con el apoyo económico de su hijo quien le da una mensualidad, pero ella prefiere mantenerse ocupada para distraerse, y así sentirse tranquila, teniendo planes de ampliar su negocio y abrir una bodega de venta de abarrotes en su casa. Por tanto éste será su  préstamo número 05 con la institución MFP, espera de un pequeño préstamo para que pueda cumplir con sus objetivos. Además comenta sentirse bien con su banco comunal pues considera a sus miembros ser personas amables y responsables.
Con el monto solicitado de 1200 nuevos soles lo invertirá en la compra de golosinas al por mayor para surtir su negocio, y con la diferencia desea comenzar con el negocio de abarrotes comprando de a poco.
texts.en:
Forty two-year old Tania is a hardworking and enthusiastic woman, in addition to being cheerful and friendly.  She is separated from her partner.  She lives with her mother and her three children who are 14, 9 and 3 years old, comfortably set up in their own house.

The business that Lucia has is selling snacks at a counter that she sets up in front of her house every day.  She started three years ago with an individual loan, and was able to win the appreciation and loyalty of her customers, the majority of whom are her neighbors, thanks to her good service and friendly way of treating them, in addition to counting on her mother's help in attending to customers.

She likes her business because it generates additional economic income and also allows her to socialize with her neighbors.  She also comments that it allows her to have an occupation and feel productive.  Now that she receives financial assistance from her son who gives her a monthly payment, she prefers to keep herself occupied to amuse herself and thus have peace of mind, as she has plans to grow her business and open a small grocery store in her house.  

Therefore, this will be her fifth loan with MFP.  She is hoping for a small loan to realize her goals.  With the requested amount of 1200 nuevo soles, she will invest in the purchase of wholesale snacks to stock her business, and with the profits she wishes to start her grocery business, buying little by little.

loans.use: to buy wholesale snacks.

loans.name: Francisco

texts.en:
Francisco, 70 has been farming cacao for 20 years. Together with his wife Brigida, Francisco has raised seven children and helped bring up an innumerable number of grandchildren – literally, he couldn’t say how many there were. He lives with Brigida and their grandson Mark, who just graduated high school with a major in agriculture, and kindly helped translate in the gathering of this information. Francisco's native language is Maya Mopan. 

Francisco is in the process of transferring his profound knowledge accumulated during 20 years of farming cacao, the sole source of income for his family, to his grandson. Like many of his peers, Mark is faced with the choice between farming and scarcely available employment in town. Mark says he wants to expand the scope of Francisco's farm to introduce some fresh vegetables, and to experiment with making and applying organic fertilizer. He also hopes to utilize his experience in food processing by using the fresh veg to make products that are not available locally. 

By being able to include his grandson in the ranks of hired help to assist with cleaning and pruning this season, Francisco will invest in the farm while also making a human capital investment to provide opportunity for his grandson to explore farm-related forms of sustenance. Cleaning and pruning is a key investment when it comes to cacao as it eases access to the trees for harvesting, prevents spread of mold infestation and increases yields in the coming harvest season.

loans.use: To clean and prune 5 acres of cacao farm in preparation for the 2013 harvest season.

loans.name: Felipe

texts.en:
Felipe, 58, lives with his wife, son, and grandson. He’s been growing cacao for most of his adult life - 30 years. “I like farmers. We have to work otherwise we don’t have anything. It’s hard, but it’s a farmer’s life,” says Felipe. 

Beside cacao, Felipe also receives income from corn sold at the Punta Gorda market, one hour down the road from San Jose, as well as beans and yams sold locally. He has used this money to invest in one of few solar panels in the village of San Jose, Toledo District, which is not connected to the grid due to poor road access. The solar panel is hooked to a battery and an inverter to provide electricity for stable phone use and light. What helped Felipe beat his peers in installing electricity in the home? “I never neglect anything,” he says, and lives by it. 

Felipe will use the loan to invest in cleaning his cacao plots. Cleaning means cutting the underbrush to clear access to the trees for pruning and harvesting and is fundamental in preventing spread of mold in the rainy season. Cacao farms located in lowland tropical forest require cleaning every 3-4 months. 

An entrepreneur at heart, Felipe is all about diversifying his crops and is one of few farmers to grow fresh vegetables – cabbage, tomato and peppers among others on his farm. Why diversify? “Corn is just not tasty without the pepper sauce to go with it,” he told us in perfect English – his second language after Maya Mopan.

loans.use: To hire help to clean 4 acres of cacao farm.

loans.name: Catarino

texts.en:
An experienced farmer, and relatively new to cacao, Catarino planted his first two acres in 2000. Having expanded to another plot of four acres in 2005, he now manages among the biggest farms in Maya Mountain Cacao's network. Catarino lives in the village of San Jose with his wife Isidora and two kids, with another four already living outside the home. 

Farming has been Catarino’s bread and butter since the beginning of days. “Farming is my life. I have no education other than my farm,” he says proudly. His wife Isidora helps out with the farm, primarily with harvesting, fermentation and drying. Catarino is one of few farmers that prefers to manage the processing before passing it onto buyers, and sells as much as 500 lbs of dry cacao and probably double that in wet cacao yearly. 

A true enthusiast of working the land, Catarino says farming is not that hard. “You have no boss, you’re your own boss.” Having no help around the farm, as his older children work in a nearby shrimp farm and youngest are still infants, Catarino is used to hiring help to manage to clean and prune his cacao farm. Pruning and cleaning is a key investment when it comes to cacao, as it eases access to the trees for harvesting, prevents spread of mold infestation and increases yields in the coming harvest season. As many farmers in San Jose, Catarino speaks his native Maya Mopan as well as English.

loans.use: To hire help with cleaning, pruning and harvesting his six acre cacao farm and purchase a cleaning blade.

loans.name: Rafael

texts.en:
Rafael, 45, is a father of 12 children, with the youngest aged 2 and oldest aged 25. Like about a third of farmers in the Maya Mountain Cacao network, Rafael lives in the village of San Jose, in the district of Toledo, where he’s been farming 4 acres of cacao for twenty years. 

Cacao is the sole source of income for Rafael's family, and his favorite crop because it has a market. “The problem is you cannot do a lot, because poor farmers don’t have finance to invest [in their farms]. That’s why we’re looking for loans,” he told Maya Mountain Cacao. Rafael's first loan will go towards cleaning, which for cacao farmers means removing the underbrush in order to plant new seedlings, prepare for pruning or harvesting by opening pathways and access to the trees. 

Rafael recently expanded the scope of his cacao farm by transplanting – moving seedlings from bags into the ground – 300 trees. Planting new seedlings is a long-term investment, as cacao trees take 3-5 years to start producing pods. 

Investment in the farm facilitated by loans translates to investment in his children, 5 of whom are currently enrolled in school. Besides taking the kids away from helping around the farm, school in Belize has annual tuition costs that are prohibitive for many Maya farmers in Toledo. Rafel's older kids followed his example by taking up cacao farming themselves.

loans.use: To hire help with cleaning his farm of almost 1,000 cacao trees.

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
Juan is a cacao farmer in San Jose. Juan, aged 62, and his wife Damiana brought up seven children, five of who have set up cacao farms close to their parents’ land. Juan, a cacao farmer of 30 years, has been acting as a certain hub for his kids’ entrepreneurial activity revolving around cacao by passing down know-how and an example of how cacao farming can be instrumental to sustaining a family. 

Juan is very diligent with maintenance of his cacao farm, which results in increasing yields. Cacao farms are literally in the middle of the jungle, as they require shade and nutrients from timber trees to keep producing cacao for many decades, making cleaning necessary every three to four months. Moreover, cleaning makes for easier access to trees and helps fight fungal diseases that spread through the pores in cacao pods. 

Maya Mountain Cacao’s buying day in San Jose is Sunday. The sight of the long trail leading to the road from their farms, when Juan and his sons descend from their farms with full buckets of wet cacao, is nothing short of extraordinary.  “I depend on cacao, it gives me some income – not much, but it helps,” he told Maya Mountain Cacao. In the future, Juan hopes to plant more trees in his own farm to have more income for his wife and himself. Like many farmers in San Jose, Juan is bilingual and speaks Mopan Maya as well as English.

loans.use: To invest in cleaning his 2 acres and helping his sons clean their plots.

loans.name: Alfonso

texts.en:
Alfonso 72, lives in the village of San Jose with his wife Isabela and two children. Asked to recount how many children he has, Alfonso counts studiously naming different villages where they all live. 

Alfonso has been farming for 30 years, and works one of the bigger cacao farms in the area, spread out in 3 plots encompassing 4 acres and around 1,600 producing trees. One of the most productive families in the Maya Mountain Cacao network, Alfonso’s farm has been under constant expansion. “The happiest moments are when the trees are producing well and we have you guys here buying every weekend,” Alfonso told MMC, adding that on the few occasions when there’s no production to sell it really feels like he’s losing out, but that’s cacao. There’s money to be made in cacao, and if everything goes perfect and he manages to keep the diseases in check, he says he’ll be a rich man.  

Alfonso is getting ready for cleaning the underbrush surrounding his cacao trees before the upcoming harvest season. Cacao pod production is picking up slowly and will reach full swing in March-April and continue until it slows again In July-August. Cleaning is a routine activity on shade-grown cacao farms in tropical lowlands and needs to be repeated every three to four months. It is necessary to clear access to the trees for pruning, harvesting and or planting new seedlings as well as to prevent fungus diseases common in the rainy season. 

Alfonso got introduced to cacao when his father started planting even before the big push in the industry when Hershey’s arrived to Belize in the early 90’s and introduced a new market and seed varietals from Costa Rica.

loans.use: To hire help with cleaning his 3 plots of cacao in preparation for the upcoming harvest season.

loans.name: Santiago

texts.en:
Santiago, 53, and his wife Margarita live in the village of Indian Creek, close to the highway connecting southern Belize to the ex capital of Belize City. Road infrastructure means connection to the electric grid, but also higher expenses due to power bills.

Santiago, a father of six, lives with his wife and their youngest, a 17-year-old son. Having initially tried to manage a teaching job alongside farming, he opted to join the ranks of many farmers making their land their full-time job and are looking sustain their families by tapping into new markets for cash crops. To diversify his income stream, Santiago has kept his eyes and ears open about different market opportunities, this has led him to expand to pumpkin, a high-demand crop on the neighboring Guatemala market. Moreover, there is pre-harvest financing for pumpkin, whereas until now there were virtually no financing mechanisms in place for cacao farmers. Santiago has been investing his income in home improvement and diversifying his food supply, such as his recently installed small-scale tilapia ponds.

Cacao farming has proved to be risky business for Santiago, whose crop was devastated by Hurricane Iris in 2001, and again in 2007 by a fire that spread from a neighboring farm. Persistent in his efforts, however, he replanted every time, and even transplanted 500 new seedlings in September of 2012 to expand his cacao farm, which has 30-year-old trees. Cacao trees take three to five years to begin producing pods and continue at full capacity for 60-70 years. Farmers have to routinely clean and prune their cacao trees to ease access for harvesting, prevent spread of mold infestation and increase yields in the coming harvest season.

loans.use: To clean his cacao farm of close to 1,000 mature trees and 500 seedlings.

loans.name: Eladio

texts.en:
Eladio boasts an exemplary family, household and farm. Eladio and his wife Virginia have brought up 15 children, of which the youngest Jahir will turn 5 in January and oldest, Adalia, is 34. Add to that some 13 grandchildren and spouses of the 10 live-in kids and you can picture this famous family from San Pedro Columbia. 

Most westerners have a hard time even imagining anything past a couple of children, but Eladio and Virginia have embraced each without fail and have worked out parenting to an art. Visitors from around the world have been visiting this beautiful family and their farm since they started a sustainable tourism enterprise. “It’s lucky to meet my brothers and sisters around the world just through a little garden,” Eladio says enthusiastically. Most of the family is trilingual, as Eladio comes from a Mopan Maya speaking environment and Virginia's background is Q'eqchi', and everybody also speaks English on top of the two Maya tongues. 

Beside cacao, they grow more exotic crops like mango, coconut, ginger, lemongrass and Jamaican lime. “I grow whatever the birds or the agouti [type of rodent]bring. That’s how an agouti works. I keep stashing the seeds also,” Eladio assures us with a huge smile. The 31-acre farm has been key in sustaining the numerous family and also served as a source of learning for the family and now visitors from abroad. Eladio and Virginia’s farm is a prime example of integrated farming, where timber and fruit trees abound in harmony and soil is enriched by composting underbrush cleared for pathways to access the crop. Integrated farming brings opportunities for soil enrichment, but also means more work cleaning, pruning and raking the underbrush to transform it to compost. Regular cleaning is indispensable for cacao farms on tropical lowlands as good soil, rain and shade make for prime conditions for growth. “Everybody wants to be a student these days. I want my kids to be farmers,” says Eladio.

loans.use: To hire help to clean 15 acres of cacao and rake cleaned underbrush for compost.

loans.name: Emako Group

texts.en:
Mary is pictured on the right with her hand raised amongst her Emako Group members. The 20 of them, 14 women and 6 men, are farmers in Butere District. Farming inputs will be delivered to her on credit consisting of the necessary materials to plant ½ acre of maize and sorghum.

Mary first enrolled with One Acre Fund during the 2011 Long Rains season and is now preparing to be a One Acre Fund farmer during the 2013 Long Rains season. Mary joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer, to access the best input prices, to rest assured of reliable input delivery, to grow enough food for the family and to use the increased profits to send her children to school.

Mary described her harvest as very good last year, but believes she can have an even better one this year. She plans to spend the money that she earns from her next harvest on sending her children to school, repairing her home, saving for the future and perhaps investing in another business.

For the 2013 Long Rains season, Mary’s group members will take input loans of ½ acre each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 10 acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Ubania Del Carmen

texts.es: La cliente es una microempresaria de éxito quien tiene una barbería desde hace 8 años, es una persona casada, con dos hijos y el crédito lo requiere para remodelar el local del negocio para así ofrecer un buen servicio a la clientela, lo invertirá también en la compra de accesorios como tijeras, toallas, máquinas para rasurar, peines, cosméticos etc.
texts.en: She’s a successful micro businesswoman who has had a barber shop for 8 years.  She’s married with two children and needs the loan to remodel her shop to provide better customer service.  She will also use it to buy tools like scissors, towels, electric shavers, combs, cosmetics, etc.

loans.use: to buy tools and equipment and to make physical improvements to the shop.

loans.name: Yahoska Rafaela

texts.es: Yahosca es una mujer casada, con un hijo menor de cuido se dedica a vender ropa, cosméticos variados de la Avon desde hace cinco años. Tiene 24 años  y es emprendedora. El crédito lo invertirá en la compra de ropa variada, cosméticos de la Avon como perfumen, delineadores, colonias, crema para cuerpo, crema para manos, etc.
texts.en: Yahosca is a married woman who has a minor child in her care.  She's had a business selling clothing and a variety of Avon cosmetics for 5 years.  She is a 24 year-old small-businesswoman.  She will invest this loan in the purchase of a variety of clothing and Avon cosmetics such as perfume, eyeliner, body cream, hand cream, etc.

loans.use: to buy a variety of clothing and Avon cosmetics such as perfumes, men's colognes, creams, makeup, etc.

loans.name: Jacqueline Del Carmen

texts.es: Jacqueline tiene 46 años de edad, casada y con tres hijos mayores  que juntos con su mama  le ayudan  a mirar  el negocio, es propietaria de una pulpería en su domicilio desde hace seis años consecutivos. El crédito  lo invertirá en la compra de granos básicos de pulpería como arroz, frijoles, azúcar, aceite, carne de res, carne de pollo, papel higiénico etc.
texts.en: Jacqueline, 46, is married and has three adult children who together with her mother help her with the business.  She owns a home-based grocery store that she’s had for six consecutive years.  She will use the loan to buy basic grains like rice and beans, sugar, oil, beef, chicken, toilet paper, etc. for the grocery store.

loans.use: to buy merchandise to stock her store.

loans.name: Maria Emerita

texts.es: María Emérita es una empresaria emprendedora quien tiene una pulpería en su casa desde hace 20 años, es casada, con tres hijos adolescentes. El crédito lo solicita para invertir en el negocio  en inventario tales como arroz, frijoles, azúcar, aceite, carne de res, carnes de pollo, productos lácteos, gaseosas variadas, cigarrillos etc.
texts.en: María Emérita is an enterprising businesswoman who has had a grocery store in her house for 20 years.  She is married and has three adolescent children. She is requesting the loan to invest in inventory for her business, such as rice, beans, sugar, oil, beef, chicken, milk products, various sodas, cigarettes, etc.

loans.use: to buy rice, beans, sugar, oil, toilet paper, various sodas, cigarettes, etc.

loans.name: Leticia Odon

texts.es: La socia es Leticia quien tiene una carnicería y refresquería desde hace cinco años en su domicilio. Tiene tres hijos y es casada, ella inicio su negocio vendiendo refresco. El crédito lo invertirá en remodelar el local brindando buen servicio, higiene y seguridad para sus productos y la clientela.
texts.en: Leticia has had a butcher shop and refreshment stall in her home for five years. She has three children and is married.  She started her business selling sodas.  Leticia will invest the loan in remodeling her business premises to provide good service, hygiene and safety for her products and her customers.

loans.use: to invest in construction materials to improve her business premises and offer good service, hygiene and safety for her products and her clients.

loans.name: Carmen Del Rosario

texts.es:
Carmen es una microempresaria que hecha y vende tortillas en su casa de habitación desde hace cinco años.

Tiene dos trabajadoras en el negocio quienes les paga su salario generando empleo a dos cabezas de familias, el crédito lo invertirá en la compra de maíz, leña, cal, etc.
texts.en:
Carmen has run a small business making and selling tortillas in her house for the past five years. She employs two female workers, thus providing an income for two heads of households.

The money from the loan will be used to buy corn, firewood, lime etc.

loans.use: buy corn, firewood, lime etc.

loans.name: Eliseth De Los Ángeles

texts.es: Elizeth hace y vende nacatamales en su domicilio desde hace 10 años, inicia su negocio vendiendo ropa usada, zapatos de segunda, carteras y que actualmente ejerce ese negocio. Con  los nacatamales tiene seis puntos de ventas en su ciudad lo que genera empleos a varias cabezas de familia de su  localidad. El crédito lo invertirá en la compra de pacas usadas, carteras de segunda, materia prima para hacer nacatamales como carne de cerdo, hojas de chagüites, arroz, perecederos, etc.
texts.en: Eliseth has been making and selling nacatamales, a typical dish made primarily from corn and pork, in her home for 10 years.  She started her business selling used clothing, second-hand shoes, and wallets.  She still maintains this business.  She sells the nacatamales in six places in her city, which generates employment for various people in her area.  The loan will be invested in buying used packs, second-hand wallets, and raw materials to make nacatamales, such as pork, chagüite leaves, rice, perishables, etc.

loans.use: to buy raw materials, such as corn, rice, pork, chagüite leaves, condiments, etc.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.es:
Lucía, de 37 años, es una mujer buena y muy responsable, es conviviente con Geno y juntos son padres de 3 hijos cuyas edades son 20, 14 y 6 años respectivamente, vive en su casa propia junto a todos los miembros de su familia. 
El trabajo de Lucía está orientado a la reparación y mantenimiento de motos y mototaxis. Tiene su taller instalado en su casa y ahí se encarga de arreglar todos los vehículos que a diario le entregan para dejarlo en óptimas condiciones. Realiza esta actividad desde hace 2 años y trabaja con la ayuda de su cónyuge que le ayuda a suplir las necesidades de su amplia clientela. Tiene mucho acceso al público ya que se encuentra ubicado en una zona muy concurrida por las personas y de fluido tránsito vehicular. También tiene dos mototaxis que alquila diariamente. Eventualmente vende comida en los aserraderos de la ciudad. Le gusta mucho su trabajo, eso le ha permitido ganarse el respeto de sus clientes y consolidar su prestigio con la calidad de su trabajo final. Espera implementar su taller con muchas más herramientas para que su trabajo se ejecute con mejores resultados y en menos tiempo de lo establecido. Este es el crédito individual numero 2 con la institución MFP, por tanto agradece a todas las personas que hacen posible su financiamiento para continuar con sus objetivos y crecimiento programado, además esta muy decidida a cumplir una vez más con sus pagos de manera puntual como lo hizo hasta ahora en sus créditos anteriores, le agrada mucho ser cliente de la institución ya que le brindan todo el apoyo necesario para seguir adelante. Con el monto solicitado 2500 soles, comprará algunas piezas y repuestos que usa en la refacción de vehículos como embrague, cadenas, rodajes, llantas y otros.
texts.en:
Thirty-seven-year-old Lucía is a good and very responsible woman.  She lives with Geno, and together they are parents to three children, ages 20, 14, and 6 years old, respectively.  She lives in her own house with all the members of her family.

Lucía's work is in the repair and maintenance of motorcycles and motorbikes.  Her workshop is located in her house.   She is in charge of fixing all the vehicles that are brought in to her daily, putting them in their best condition. 

She has been doing this work for the past two years and works with the help of her partner; he helps to meet the needs of her broad clientele.  She has a lot of access to the public, since she is located in a very busy zone with a lot of people and frequent traffic.  She also has two motorbikes that she rents out daily.  Possibly, she will sell food in the sawmills of the city too.  

She likes her work a lot; it has allowed her to win the respect of her customers and to strengthen her reputation with the quality of her final work.  She hopes to supply her workshop with many more tools so that she can execute her work with better results and in less time.   

The is her second individual loan with MFP.  Therefore, she is thankful to all the people who make her financing possible in order to continue with her objectives and projected growth.  She is also very determined to again make the punctual payments, just as she did with her past loans.  

She is very pleased to be a client of the institution; they have already offered her all the necessary support to continue moving forward.  With the amount she has requested (2500), she will buy parts and spare parts that she replaces in vehicles, like the clutch, chains, wheels, tires, and others.

loans.use: to buy parts and spare parts that she replaces in vehicles, like the clutch, chains, wheels, tires, and others.

loans.name: Magda

texts.es:
Magda, es una mujer trabajadora y empeñosa, le gustan los restos y tiene muchas ganas de salir adelante. Es conviviente con Víctor quien es obrero y padre de su  hijo de 22 años de edad por quien se esfuerza en brindarles una mejor calidad de vida. Juntos habitan cómodamente su propia casa que compraron con mucho esfuerzo. La actividad que realiza Magda es la venta de bebidas gaseosas y refrescos de frutas orgánicas para esto cuenta con una refrigeradora que compró con un préstamo de MFP, y la instalo en su casa, de ahí atiende muy amablemente a sus clientes ganándose sus preferencias. 
Se inició con su propio capital y con el apoyo de su pareja, comprando en pequeñas cantidades fue juntando su dinero y lo volvía a invertir, aumentando de esa manera su stock de mercaderías. 
Considera a su negocio rentable por las ganancias que le deja y la demanda que tiene sus productos por lo caluroso de la zona. Además comenta que no tenía apuros económicos, sino que quiso tener una ocupación para su tiempo libre, así sentirse una persona productiva y apoyar a su pareja con los gastos del hogar.
Espera en un futuro abrir otro negocio de venta de abarrotes, acondicionando una bodega en su casa. Por tanto solicita 800 nuevos soles, para invertirlo en la compra de bebidas como gaseosas de diversos sabores y marcas así tener un stock variad. También en la compra de frutas, buscando precios cómodos por su compra en volumen, así tendrá mayores ganancias.
texts.en:
Magda is a hardworking, dedicated woman who enjoys challenges and very much wants to get ahead.  She lives with Victor who is a laborer and the father of their 22-year-old son who she strives to provide with a better quality of life.  They all live together in her house that they bought thanks to much effort.  Magda’s activity is selling soft-drinks and organic fruit beverages and to do so she has a refrigerator she bought with an MFP loan that she installed at home and she kindly tends to customers there winning over their patronage.  She started out with her own capital and with support from her spouse buying in small amounts and when she’d gathered more money together she’d reinvest thus increasing her stock merchandise.

She considers her business to be profitable because of the profits it yields and demand her products have due to the zone’s hot weather.  She also comments that she had no economic difficulties but wanted to have something to do in her free time to feel productive and help her spouse with household expenses.

She hopes in future to open another business selling groceries; she will set up a store at home to be near her children and provide them the care they need.  This will be MFP loan #1.  She’s happy to know that she’ll have financial support to continue forward with her business.  She also commits to make her payments like she’s done in previous loans.  She’s also happy to be part of her communal group because she considers the group to be united and supportive.

She will use the requested 800 new soles to buy soft-drinks in assorted flavors and brands to have a varied stock available.  She will also buy fruit seeking out the best prices for volume purchases so her profits will be higher.

loans.use: to buy soft-drinks and fruit.

loans.name: Okendakala Group

texts.en:
Okendakala is a group of 26 farmers in Busia District, represented by Ernest. The group has 19 women and 7 men. Ernest is on the right of the photo with his hand raised. Farming inputs will be delivered to him on credit, consisting of the necessary materials to plant a ½-acre of maize and sorghum. The 2013 Long Rains season will be Ernest’s first season with One Acre Fund. He joined this year in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer, access the best input prices and rest assured of reliable input delivery, grow enough food for his family, and use his increased profits to send his children to school.

Ernest thought his harvest last year was poor. He hopes that, as a One Acre Fund farmer, he can have an excellent harvest. He plans to spend the money that he earns from his next harvest on buying a plow for digging. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Ernest’s group members will take loans of ½-acre's' worth of inputs each. In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 13 acres of land.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Bidii Yetu Group

texts.en:
Redemtah's group is called the Bidii Yetu Group. It is located in the Busia District and is comprised of 15 women and three men. The group is led by Redemtah, who is pictured on the right with her hand raised. She describes her harvest last year as poor. Redemtah is a new One Acre Fund farmer and is excited for the 2013 Long Rains season. She joined the fund to access hybrid seed and fertilizer, obtain the best input prices, be assured of reliable delivery, and grow enough food for her family. She hopes to be able to join the ranks of One Acre Fund farmers that have doubled their harvest in their first year of the program.  
 
Redemtah is requesting a loan to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer to plant a half-acre with sorghum and maize. Group members will each receive half-acre input loans during the 2013 season. In total, the Bidii Yetu group will receive inputs for nine acres of land. Redemtah plans to use her harvest profits to repair her home, buy livestock, save for the future, send her children to school, and perhaps invest in another business.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer to plant a half-acre with sorghum and maize

loans.name: Tumaini Group

texts.en:
Tumaini Group, located in Busia District, consists of 14 women and 8 men led by Catherine, pictured on the right with her hand raised.  She is receiving an input loan for ½ an acre of maize and sorghum cultivation. The 2013 Long Rains season will be Catherine’s first season with One Acre Fund. She joined this year in order to grow enough food for the family.

Catherine described her harvest last year as good, but hopes she can have an even better one as a One Acre Fund farmer. She hopes that her profits from the 2013 Long Rains season can be used to buy livestock as an investment for the future. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive a loan for ½ an acre of agricultural inputs, for a total of 11 acres worth of loans.

The field officer is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Kech Ongo Mbala Group

texts.en:
Kech Ongo Mbala is a group of 13 farmers in Butere District represented by Ayub. The group has 10 women and 3 men. Ayub is on the right of the photo with his hand raised. Farming inputs will be delivered to him on credit consisting of the necessary materials to plant ½ an acre of maize and sorghum. Ayub is a new One Acre Fund farmer and is excited for the 2013 Long Rains season. He joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer, access the best input prices, rest assured of reliable input delivery, grow enough food for the family and use increased profits to send his children to school.

Ayub described his harvest last year as good, but hopes he can have an even better one as a One Acre Fund farmer. He plans to spend the money that he earns from his next harvest on sending his children to school, saving for the future, buying livestock and perhaps investing in another business. During the 2013 Long Rains season, each group member will receive ½ an acre of agricultural inputs on credit. Ayub’s group will receive 6.5 acres worth of inputs on credit.

Hellen, one of the farmers of Kech Ongo Mbala Group, chose to drop out of the program after the Kiva photo was taken. She is still pictured above.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Bidii Group

texts.en:
Bidii Group is located in Butere District. It is a group of 14 women and 14 men led by Margret, who is pictured on the right with her hand raised.  She is receiving an input loan for one half of an acre of maize and sorghum cultivation. Margret joined One Acre Fund during the 2011 Long Rains season and is now enrolling in the 2013 Long Rains season. Margret joined One Acre Fund in order to gain access to hybrid seed and fertilizer and grow enough food for her family.

Margret reports that before One Acre Fund, she was able to grow about 8 bags of maize per acre, but with her One Acre Fund input loan, during the 2012 Long Rains season, she harvested 18 bags per acre. She plans to spend the money that she earns from her next harvest on sending her children to school and perhaps investing in another business. For the 2013 Long Rains season, Margret’s group members will take input loans of one-half acre each.  In total, this group will receive input loans for use on 14 acres of land.

The field officer is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize and sorghum.

loans.name: Onix De Jesus

texts.es: Onix de 50 años, habita con su hija de 26 años en uno de los barrios mas tradicionales de la ciudad de Barranquilla, su temperamento alegre y cordial, la hacen merecedora de una gran popularidad en el barrio y ella la aprovecha para fortalecer sus negocios mediante los cuales se dedica a la preparación de almuerzo y comidas, además y de vender cervezas y gaseosas en un punto frio,  que es muy concurrido. Su primera iniciativa comercial data de hace 8 años, cuando trabajó en un restaurante del centro de la ciudad y su propietaria se enfermó,  debiendo cerrarlo. Esto    generó  a Onix, la necesidad de trabajar independientemente y estar mas cerca del cuidado de su hija, así fue como en su propia casa, empezó vendiendo almuerzos y poco a poco hizo crecer su negocio, aportándole su mayor dinamismo y disciplina de trabajo. Cuando inició lo hizo en la época de carnaval y esto fue una oportunidad para medir sus ventas y estimular sus deseos de hacerlo crecer y sacar adelante a su hija, como lo logró pues estudia enfermería y muy pronto la terminará. En la actualidad sus ventas se han incrementado y su demanda crece cada vez mas, por eso tener un capital de trabajo, para invertir y satisfacer a su clientela, se convierte en todo un desafío. Esta es la razón por la cual acude a un cedikiva,  primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará materias primas, hará mejoramiento del local, para tener un espacio mejor organizado, que despierte a su clientela, el deseo de regresar a su negocio a consumir los productos que ofrece. Su mayor sueño de prosperidad es lograr que su hija termine su carrera profesional y que tenga un futuro lleno de muchos éxitos.
texts.en:
Onix, 50 years old, lives with her 26-year-old daughter in one of the traditional neighborhoods of the city of Barranquilla. Her temperament is happy and cordial, making her worthy of her great popularity in the neighborhood. She takes advantage of this to strengthen her businesses, which involve the preparation of lunches and other meals, in addition to selling cold beer and soft drinks. Her establishment gets very crowded.

Her first commercial venture began eight years ago, when she worked at a restaurant in the city center and the owner got sick, making them close the restaurant. This led to Onix working independently and being closer to caring for her daughter, since she was at home. Onix began selling lunches and, little by little, she grew her business, providing her best energy and discipline to the job. When she started, it was the time of Carnaval, which was a good opportunity to test her sales and stimulate her interests in growing her business and moving her daughter forward. She has been able to do so since her daughter is studying nursing and will soon finish school. 

Lately, her sales have been increasing and she has a greater demand every day. For this reason, having working capital to invest and satisfying her customers have become challenging. This is why she is requesting a Kiva loan, so that she can have a better organized space, which attracts customers to come and eat the food she prepares. Her greatest dream is that her daughter will finish her professional studies and have a successful future full.

loans.use: to buy raw materials and improve her establishment

loans.name: Purificacion

texts.es:
La socia Purificacion se dedica al negocio de transporte,la socia junto con su esposo se dedican al negocio de servicio de taxi,la socia administra el carro y su esposo maneja el carro,la socia ya tiene 6 años en este negocio y le va muy bien.La socia solicita el credito para comprar llantas.

La socia esta contenta con el credito y se compromete a cumplir los pagos de sus cuota.
texts.en:
Purificacion makes a living in the transportation business.  Together with her husband, they have a taxi service.  She manages the car and her husband drives the car.  She already has been working in this field for six years and it is going very well.  She is requesting the loan to buy tires.

She is happy with the loan and promises to repay her installments.

loans.use: to buy tires and spare car parts.

loans.name: Flora Argentina

texts.es: Flora es una microempresaria originaria de Masaya ella se dedica a destace de cerdo y venta de refrescos naturales desde hace 7 años, es una mujer que esta casada y tiene 48 años de edad, el crédito lo invertirá en la compra de cerdos en pie para luego destazar al cerdo y vender sus carnes.
texts.en: Flora is a micro-businesswoman and is originally from Masaya.  She makes a living slaughtering pigs and selling natural refreshments.  She has done this for seven years.  She is a married woman and is forty-eight years old.  She will invest the loan money in the purchase of live pigs to later slaughter and sell the meat.

loans.use: to buy live pigs.

loans.name: Los Chilamates Group

texts.es: Este grupo está formado por tres socias emprendedoras que se dedican cada socio a sus diferentes actividades, una de ellas es María Eusebia que tiene una pulpería desde hace 5 años, es madre soltera con tres hijos menores, de tener credito con la institucion tiene  cinco años .El credito lo invertira en la compra de carne de res, carne de pollo, productos lácteos, arroz, azucar, frijoles, papel nhigienico, jabon de lavar ropa, jabon de lavar trastes etc. Olga vende repostería y Patricia Guadalupe vende ropa usada y repostería.
texts.en:
This group is formed of three enterprising members who each make a living from their different micro-business activities.  

One of the members is María Eusebia.  She has had a grocery store for five years.  She is a single mother of three young children, and has been a client of the institution for five years.  She will invest the loan in the purchase of beef, chicken, dairy products, rice, beans, sugar, toilet paper, detergent, soap etc.
  
Olga sells prepared pastries.  Patricia Guadalupe sells used clothing and prepared pastries.

loans.use: to buy grains like rice, beans, sugar, beef, chicken, dairy products, etc.

loans.name: Lourdes Group

texts.es: Grupo formado por tres socios emprendedores originarios de Masaya, una de ellas es Claudia Fabiola que se dedica a comercializar venta de gallinas desde hace 8 años. Es acompañada sus productos los vende en el mercado de Masaya, el crédito lo invertirá en la compra de gallinas, por fiestas de temporadas en épocas navideñas. María Lourdes tiene 60 años de edad y vende gallinas y Juan Francisco vende verduras de manera ambulante.
texts.en: This group consists of three entrepreneurs from Masaya, one of whom is Claudia Fabiola. She has been selling chickens for the last 8 years. She has a life partner. She sells her products in the Masaya market. She will buy chickens with the loan, as they will sell because of Christmas parties. María Lourdes is 60 years old and sells chickens, and Juan Francisco is a street vendor who sells vegetables.

loans.use: to buy chickens

loans.name: Reseda Y Sontol Group

texts.es: Este es un grupo  formado por tres socias una de ellas es Lizet de 25 años de edad se dedica a comercializar chinelas y las vende ambulante, es una mujer casada y con dos hijos menores, el crédito lo invertirá en la compra de chinelas variadas y  de diferentes estilos, Aydalina tiene 36 años de edad y vende ojuelas,y espumias, Rosa hace y vende tortillas .
texts.en: This groups is made up of three members. One of them is Lizett. She is 25 years old and works selling slippers as a mobile street vendor. She is married and has two children under 18. She will invest the loan in the purchase of assorted slippers of different styles. Aydalina is 36 years old and sells puff pastries and meringues. Rosa makes and sells tortillas.

loans.use: to buy different styles of slippers.

loans.name: Girasoles Group

texts.es: Es un grupo formado por cuatros socios emprendedores uno de ellos es Bismar que vende ropa usada desde hace 4 años y tiene 3 hijos menores el crédito lo invertirá en la compra de pacas de ropa usada, Patricia vende ropa usada y cosméticos, Ana Cristina vende también ropa usada y Yamir vende frutas.
texts.en: This group is comprised of four enterprising members. One of the members is Bismar, who has been selling used clothing for four years. He has three young children. He will invest this loan into buying packages of used clothing. Patricia sells used clothing and cosmetics, Ana Cristina also sells used clothing, and Yamir sells fruit.

loans.use: to buy packages of used clothing

loans.name: Ross Mistica Group

texts.es: Este grupo está formado por tres socios emprendedores que se dedican cada uno a sus actividades uno de ellos es Luis Alberto quien tiene ocho años de vender prendas de oro, es casado y tiene cinco años de estar trabajando con la institución, el crédito lo invertirá en la compra de prendas de oro como anillos de graduación, pulseras, brazaletes, cadenas para hombre, cadenas para damas etc. Yovana vende fritanga los fines de semana y Catalina tiene una pulpería en su domicilio.
texts.en: This group is comprised of three enterprising members who each have their own sectors of work. One of the members is Luis Alberto, who has eight years of experience in selling gold jewelry. He is married and has been working with this institution for five years. He will invest this loan into buying gold jewelry such as graduation rings, bracelets, armbands, and men's and women's chains. Yovana sells fried food on the weekends and Catalina has a small grocery store in her home.

loans.use: to buy gold jewelry such as graduation rings, bracelets, armbands, and men's and women's chains.

loans.name: Las Marias Group

texts.es: Es un grupo formado por cuatro socias emprendedoras una de ella es Flor de María que se dedica a vender tortilla, pinol, pinolillo, chicha, atolillo, pozol, tiene 17 años de tener experiencia vende sus productos en el mercado de Masaya, el crédito lo invertirá en la compra de maíz, leñas, rodaminas, vainillas, frambuesa, bolsas etc., Silvia vende legumbres, Ana Dominga vende frutas y verduras y Evelin vende repostería ambulante.
texts.en:
This is a group formed by four women who are entrepreneurs. 

One of them is Flor de María. She sells tortillas, pinol (roasted maize flour beverage), pinolillo (cornmeal and cocoa based beverage), chicha (corn based beverage), gruel, and pozol (beverage made with corn dough often mixed with cocoa). She has 17 years experience selling her products at the market in Masaya. Her loan will be used to buy corn, firewood, rhodamine, vanilla, raspberry, bags, etc. 

Silva sells vegetables, Ana Dominga sells fruit and vegetables and Evelin sells pastry on the street.

loans.use: to buy corn, firewood, rhodamine, vanilla, raspberry, bags, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Donald  Antonio

texts.es: Donald es un emprendedor originario de Masaya su negocio es la compra y venta de elotes al por mayor y al detalle, actividad que la viene realizando desde hace 25 años, es un hombre casado, y tiene tres hijos  que le ayudan en la administración del negocio , el crédito lo invertirá en la compra de elotes de maíz.
texts.en: Donald is an entrepreneur who originates form Massaya. His business is buying and selling wholesale corn on the cob. He's been running this business for 25 years. He's a married man with 3 children who help him run the business. He'll invest the loan in buying corn on the cob.

loans.use: invest in buying wholesale corn on the cob.

loans.name: Rosita Group

texts.es: Este grupo está formado por tres socios emprendedores una de ellos es Ervin que es artesano en bambú tiene experiencia  desde hace 15 años, tiene 36 años de edad y es un negocio heredado por sus padres. El crédito lo  invertirá en materia prima como el bambú, Rosita vende legumbres y frutas y Celia vende frutas.
texts.en: This group is formed of three business-minded friends. One of them is Ervin, who is an artisan working with bamboo. He has worked with bamboo since he was 15 years old, and he is 36 years old now. He inherited the business from his parents. His share of the loan money will be used to buy raw materials such as bamboo. As for the other members of the group, Rosita sells vegetables and fruits, and Celia sells fruits.

loans.use: purchase raw materials such as bamboo.

loans.name: Vision Artesanal Group

texts.es: Este es un grupo formado por tres socios emprendedores uno de ello es Juan Manuel tiene 23 años de edad  es artesano de pinturas desde hace 10 años como negocio, pero desde su niñez ha practicado su arte como pintor. El crédito lo invertirá en la compra de materiales como pinturas, marcos de cuadro, botellas, pinceles, olio, engrapadoras, base blanca, tela dril etc. Patricia vende cosméticos y frutas y Bladimir José vende tortillas.
texts.en: This is a group made up of three enterprising members. One of them is Juan Manuel. He is 23 years old and has been painting as a business for more than ten years. But he has been been practicing his art as a painter since his childhood. He will invest his loan in purchasing materials like paints, picture frames, bottles, paint brushes, oil paint, staplers, white base, twill fabric, etc. Patricia sells cosmetics and fruit and Bladimir José sells tortillas.

loans.use: to buy materials like paint, picture frames, bottles, paint bushes, oil paint, staplers, white base, twill fabric, etc.

loans.name: Te Agradesco Señor Group

texts.es: Este es un grupo que está formado por tres socias una de ellas es Yesenia que tiene una pulpería desde hace 10 años en su domicilio, tiene 22 años y es una mujer soltera, el crédito  lo invertirá en la compra de inventario de pulpería como granos básicos arroz, frijoles, azúcar, aceites, productos lácteos, carne de res, carne de pollo, etc. Rosa vende pan y repostería ambulante y María de Jesús mercadería en general.
texts.en: This communal bank is made up of three members, one of whom is Yesenia.  She has had a small grocery in her home for 10 years.  She is 22 years old and single.  She will invest her loan in the purchase of inventory for her grocery, like basic grains, such as rice, beans, sugar, cooking oils, dairy products, beef, chicken etc.  Among the other two members, Rosa sells bread and pastries as a street vendor and María de Jesús sells general merchandise.

loans.use: to invest in the purchase of grains, like rice, beans, sugar, cooking oil, beef, chicken and dairy products.

loans.name: La Iglesia Group

texts.es: Este grupo está formado por tres socias emprendedoras una de ellas es Gilma hace 10 años se dedica a vender enchiladas y también se dedica a la agricultora en temporadas de siembras, tiene 54 años es casada y sus hijos son adultos, tiene 4 años de ser cliente de la institución, el crédito lo invertirá en la compra de materia prima como maíz, aceite, carne de res, carne de pollo, vegetales, arroz etc. Sadia hace y vende tortilla y Rosario vende cosméticos de la Avon.
texts.en:
This group consists of three entrepreneurial members. One of them is Gilma. For ten years she has sold enchiladas, and she also works in agriculture during the planting seasons. She is 54 years old. She is married and her children are adults. She has been a customer of this institution for 4 years. She will invest the loan in buying basic ingredients such as corn, oil, beef, chicken, vegetables, rice, etc. 

Sadia makes and sells tortillas, and Rosario sells Avon cosmetics.

loans.use: to buy corn, firewood, oil, beef, chicken, vegetables, rice, etc., to make enchiladas

loans.name: Fatima Del Carmen

texts.es: Fátima es una empresaria que hace y vende tortilla en su domicilio desde hace 20 años, es una mujer casada, con dos hijos. Tiene dos trabajadores quienes le ayudan en el negocio. El crédito lo invertirá en la compra de maíz, cal, leña bolsas plásticas etc.
texts.en: Fatima is an entrepreneur who makes and sells tortillas out of her home and has done so for 20 years.  She is married and has two children.  She has two employees who help her with her business and will use the money from this loan to buy dried corn, salt, firewood, plastic bags, etc.

loans.use: to buy ingredients.

loans.name: Elena Clara

texts.es: Elena tiene 42 años de edad, casada, tiene su negocio de venta de pollos desde hace 4 años. Sus productos los vende en el mercado de Masaya . El crédito lo invertirá en la compra de pollos en piezas y pollo entero para la temporada navideña.
texts.en: Elena is 42 years old, married, and has had a chicken selling business for four years.  She sells her products in the Masaya market.  She will use the money from this loan to buy chicken parts and whole chickens for the Christmas season.

loans.use: to buy poultry.

loans.name: 17 De Septiembre Group

texts.es: Grupo formado por tres socias emprendedoras una de ellas es Salvadora de Jesús que se dedica a vender ropa usada, desde hace dos años tiene tres hijos menores y es madre soltera. El crédito lo invertirá en la compra de pacas de ropa usada, Marisol vende ropa usada y ropa nueva, María Auxiliadora vende cosméticos de  la Avon.
texts.en:
This group was formed by three entrepreneurial women.  Salvadora de Jesus is one of the women and she has been selling second hand clothing for the past three years.  She is the single mother of three young children and will use the money from this loan to buy second hand clothing.
Marisol sells new and second hand clothing.  Maria Auxiliadora sells Avon brand cosmetics.

loans.use: to buy clothing.

loans.name: Fe Y Vida Group

texts.es: Este grupo está formado por cuatro socias emprendedoras una de ellas es Brenda tiene 29 años madre soltera con tres hijos menores que se dedica a la venta de fritanga los fines de semanas en su domicilio, el crédito lo invertirá en la compra de materia prima como arroz, frijoles, azúcar , aceite, instrumentos de cocinas como cacerolas, cucharones, y por la temporada cosméticos de la Avon, Eudobis hace y vende tortillas, María vende ropa usada y Juana vende nacatamales, refrescos, cosméticos y un puesto de enabas donde se vende granos básicos.
texts.en: This group is made up of four ladies.  Brenda is one of the members and is 29 years old, the single mother of three children, and sells fried foods from her home on the weekends.  She will use the money from this loan to buy supplies such as rice, beans, sugar, cooking oil, cooking utensils, such as casserole dishes, spoons and Avon cosmetics for the season.  Eudobis makes and sells tortillas.  Maria sells used clothing, and Juan sells nacatamales, soft drinks, cosmetics and basic grains from a sales stall.

loans.use: to buy supples and ingredients.

loans.name: Otrra Oportunidad Group

texts.es: Grupo formado por tres socias emprendedoras que una de ellas se dedica a la venta de ropa usada desde hace 1 años, tiene 21 años de edad con hijo y madre soltera, el crédito lo invertirá en la compra de pacas de ropa usada, Scarleth vende comida y cerveza y Jeannette tiene una venta de fritanga.
texts.en: This group is made up of three enterprising women. One of them has worked selling second-hand clothing for a year. She is 21 years old, and is a single mother with a son. She will use the loan to buy bales of used clothing. Scarleth sells food and beer and Jeanette sells fried foods.

loans.use: to buy bales of second-hand clothing.

loans.name: Guardabarranco Group

texts.es: Grupo formado por tres socias exitosas una de ellas es María Elena que se dedica a vender cosméticos de la Avon desde hace 10 años, es una mujer casada, con tres hijos menores. El crédito lo invertirá en la compra de cosméticos variados de la Avon y ropa nueva, Doris vende frijoles cocidos, hielo, helados, refrescos naturales y Yamileth vende comida ambulante en un mercado local de la capital y ropa.
texts.en: This group is made up of three successful members. One of them is María Elena, who has worked selling Avon cosmetics for 10 years. She is a married woman, with three children under 18. She will invest the loan in assorted Avon cosmetics and new clothing. Doris sells cooked beans, ice, ice cream, and natural soft drinks. Yamileth sells food and clothing as a mobile vendor in a local market in the capital.

loans.use: to buy assorted cosmetics from Avon and new clothing

loans.name: Shalon Group

texts.es: Es un grupo formado por tres socias emprendedoras una de ellas es Keyla que vende ropa nueva y sandalias desde hace 3 años, es casada y con un hijo menor, el crédito lo invertirá en la compra de ropa nueva y variada y sandalias.Aleyda vende comida y Rosa vende cosméticos variados de la Avon.
texts.en:
This group consists of three enterprising members, one of whom is Keyla, who has been selling new clothes and sandals for the past 3 years. She is married and has one child under 18.

She will use the loan to invest in new and varied clothes and sandals. Aleyda sells food and Rosa sells different Avon cosmetcs.

loans.use: to buy new and varied clothes and sandals

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es: La señora Margarita vive en una zona bastante alejada de la ciudad de Santa Cruz. En dicha zona no se cuenta con transporte público pero aquí en Bolivia se a implementado un nuevo servicio de transporte como los trufis, son vehículos de cuatro puertas que en vez de hacer un servicio de taxi lo hacen de trufis con una sola ruta definida a un barrio, la señora cuenta con un vehículo que lo hace trabajar de trufi y percibe una renta de este servicio pero como ella cuenta con dos hijos de este ingreso les alcanza para subsistir, pero en su vivienda aun le falta algunos arreglos ya que tiene dos cuartos los cuales no tienen techo, para esto es el préstamo que necesitan ya que su esposo no se encuentra en el país por que fue a buscar un futuro mejor para su familia, pero aun no ha conseguido un trabajo todavía, el crédito es para que esta familia pueda terminar de construir su casa que está incompleta y mejorar su calidad de vida.
texts.en: Señora Margarita lives in a district that is quite a distance from the city of Santa Cruz. In this area there is no public transportation, but here in Bolivia they have set up a new transportation service, such as the trufis (minibuses). They are vehicles with four doors that, instead of providing taxi service, have a single defined route to a neighborhood. Señora Margarita has a vehicle that she has working as a trufi, and she receives a rental fee for this service. But as she has two children, this income is sufficient for subsisting, but their home still needs some work, since she has two rooms that do not have a roof. The loan that she needs is for this, since her husband is not in the country, because he went to look for a better future for his family, but he still has not found work. The loan is so that this family can finish building their house, which is incomplete, and improve their quality of life.

loans.use: to finish building her house.

loans.name: Fatou's Group

texts.fr:
Ce Banc Villageois est âgé de 14 ans. Les membres qui le composent travaillent en parfaite collaboration. Leur principale activité est le commerce et l'embouche.
Fatou, debout à droite de la photo est âgée de 40 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 7 enfants dont 4 garçons et 3 filles.
Avec le prêt reçu elle compte acheter 2 moutons, l'un à 30 000f et au bout de 4 à 5 mois elle va les revendre.Elle va acheter aussi de l'arachide 100kg, le kg à 500f; et 10 bassine de bissap, le prix d'achat de la bassine à 1750f et la vente à 4000f.
Les bénéfices lui serviront à payer la scolarité de 3 enfants, d'assurer le petit déjeuner, l'achat de l'huile dont la famille aura besoin pour la préparation des repas et de se prendre en charge pour les frais médicaux.
texts.en:
This "banc villageois" is 14 years old. The members who make it up work in perfect collaboration. Their main business is shopkeeping and animal fattening.

Fatou, standing on the right in the photo is 40 years old. She is married and mother to 7 children of whom 4 are boys and 3 are girls.

With the loan received she plans to buy 2 sheep, one at 30,000f and at the end of 4 to 5 months she is going to resell them. She is also going to buy 100kg of groundnuts, each kg at 500f, and 10 basins of hibiscus flowers. The price to purchase a basin is 1,750f and it sells for 4,000f.

The profits will serve to pay for the schooling of 3 children, and to ensure breakfast and the purchase of oil which the family will need for the preparation of meals and to take care of herself for medical expenses.

loans.use: to buy 2 sheep, 10 basins of hibiscus flowers and 100kg of groundnuts.

loans.name: Ruwa Kumari

texts.en:
Ruwa Kumari is 32 year-old. She is married and has 3 children, aged 15, 14 and 10.  In 2000 she established her vegetable farming business. Working 7 days a week and 4 hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid 2 loans from Patan BPW, and used her most recent to buys seeds and fertilizer for her business. In the future, Ruwa Kumari plans to uplift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support.   

Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural. Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land. Rice (bhat), lentils (daal), and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet. With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seed and fertilizer.  With more seeds and fertilizer, a borrower is able to grow cash crops to be sold in the local market. Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year.

loans.use: to buys seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Natalia

texts.ru:
Наталия уже несколько раз пользовалась финансовыми средствами, предоставленными КИВА. Последний кредит, полученный от КИВА, она вложила в развитие своего бизнеса, и это способствовало его развитию. 
Наталия обратилась за суммой в размере 4 000 гривен, чтобы приобрести дополнительную партию товара. Наталия надеется получить хорошую выручку с этого сезона, так как дополнительные средства ей пригодятся, ведь она ждет ребенка. Со временем Наталия надеется воплотить свою давнюю мечту и открыть собственный магазин.
texts.en:
Natalia has already taken advantage of several Kiva loans. She invested the last loan into her business, which promoted its growth.

This time, Natalia requests the sum of 4,000 hryvnia in order to purchase an additional lot of merchandise. She hopes to earn good profits this season, which will come in handy as she is expecting a child. In time, Natalia hopes to realize her long-time dream of opening her own shop.

loans.use: to purchase an additional lot of merchandise

loans.name: Patricia Onorinda

texts.es:
PATRICIA ONORINDA tiene 35 años de edad es soltera tiene dos hijos de 10 y 5 años de edad, vive con los hijos en la ciudad de Chimbo.

PATRICIA ONORINDA se dedica a la venta de Ropa para damas y caballeros. Solicita el crédito para comprar calentadores, pantalones de gabardina, sueteres de hombres, camisetas, licras. 

Con la ayuda del crédito podra comprar más mercadería para satisfacer a los clientes. Las compras y las ventas las realizará en Guaranda. Los desafíos a los que se enfrenta es la competencia. 
El sueño es tener incrementar el negocio y tener un local propio.
En el tiempo libre le gusta compartir con la familia.
texts.en:
Patricia Onorinda is 35 years old, and is the single mother of two children, ages 10 and 5. She and her children live in the city of Chimbo, where she makes a living selling men's and women's clothing. She is requesting this loan in order to purchase merchandise to stock her business, including pants, shirts, men's sweaters, tights and other items which she can use to meet the demands of her clients.

Patricia buys her merchandise in Guaranda. One of the challenges she faces daily is competition from other vendors. Her dream is to grow and expand her business, and to eventually have her own physical location for her store. In her free time, Patricia likes to be with her family.

loans.use: to purchase clothing for resale, including gabardine pants, men's sweaters, shirts, tights and other items.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy is 40 years old and is married to Franklin, a father who manages their transport motorcycle. Mercy and her family live in the village of San Antonio. To help her husband, Mercy engaged herself in her general store. She has been in her business for almost three years and earns about PHP 300 a day. 

Mercy wants to have more groceries to sell, but she lacks the necessary capital. In this regard, Mercy is asking for a loan in the amount of PHP 25,000 to buy grocery items such as canned goods, noodles, assorted bread, and biscuits to sell. 

Mercy believes that, through her loan, she will be able to improve her business and increase her income to continuously secure her family’s future.

loans.use: to buy grocery items such as canned goods, noodles, assorted bread, and biscuits to sell.

loans.name: Benson

texts.en:
Benson lives in the Nanyuki area of Central province, Kenya. He owns a tea tree farming business. He started the business from the income of subsistence farming. The extract from the tea tree is used to manufacture cosmetics. He began the business of tea tree farming this year.

He learned about Milango through an employee who invited him to the group, and he joined the group with an aim of accessing credit. The main challenge in the area has been the seasonal weather. This he believes will be sorted once he purchases a water pump.

Benson is applying for a loan of 19,676 Kenya shillings to buy tea tree seedlings for the business. His extra income from the loan will be added to his savings, and he looks forward to establishing more farming by increasing the acreage.

loans.use: To buy tea tree seedlings for the business.

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is 21 years old, he is single and lives in Majengo Village, Patrick he has been a volunteer for more than 6 years. He has lead many health outreach programmes targeting the youth both in schools and in the community. Patrick  also participates in activities supporting men to stop domestic violence.. Patrick also participates in  women groups activities advising on safe water usage and general hygiene. Patrick aspires to be a nurse in near future.

The greatest challenge in performing his duties as a Community Health Worker has been low incentives and transportation, as he has to cover many household spread between far locations, the terrain can also be difficult especially during the rainy season. Having a motorcycle will enhance is work, increase the coverage and thus the number of household visited in a given period. The motorcycle will be a working tool to enhance easy and faster access to health services to the community. While not being used for community outreach activities the motorcycle will be engaged in micro-business errands such as community taxi, community courier service, milk delivery service etc bringing the needed extra incomes to the families. This is a big incentive to the CHWs who are mostly young at the beginning of their careers in the Health sector. 

Motorcycle micro business in Kenya is a thriving sector with very good returns, the motorcycle costs about USD1300,however,riders are bale to make net returns of about USD15 per day, while the loan repayment is about USD4 per day, payable in 18 months. BodAfya is a new loan product which has proved very popular with CHWs. The product is well linked with the existing CHWs public systems and networks in Kenya. It has positive benefits of supporting the community health programmes, and at the same time supporting families improve their livelihoods and incomes, resulting to a healthier and wealthier community.

loans.use: To buy a Motorcycle for Community Health Work

loans.name: Aminjon

texts.ru: Аминчон живет в районе Хамадони. Ему 27 лет. Он женат, имеет 2 детей. Аминчон хочет заниматся развозом людей. Он хочет взять кредит для ремонта своей автомашины.
texts.en: Aminjon lives in the Hamadoni region.  He is 27 years old and he is married with two children.  Aminjon wants to work as a taxi driver.  He is asking for a loan to make repairs on his car.

loans.use: to repair his car

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en:
Godfrey lives in the Nanyuki area of Central province, Kenya. He owns a tea tree farming business. He started the business from the income he earned from subsistence farming. The extract from tea tree is used to manufacture cosmetics. He began the business of tea tree farming this year.

He learned about Milango through an employee who invited him to the group and he joined the group with the aim of accessing credit. The main challenge in the area has been the seasonal weather. This he believes will be sorted out once he purchases a water pump.

Godfrey is applying for a loan of 11,526 Kenya shillings to buy tea tree seedlings for the business. His extra income from the loan will be added to his savings and he looks forward to establishing the farm by increasing the acreage.

loans.use: To buy tea tree seedlings for the business.

loans.name: Alexander

texts.en:
Alexander is a 28-year-old married man. He describes himself to be hard working. He operates a business where he provides transportation services to customers within his area. He has been involved in this business for two years. His business is located within a busy residential area, and his primary customers are local residents. He describes his biggest business challenge to be stiff competition within the area. 

He will use the 20,000 KES (Kenyan shillings) loan to buy motorcycle spare parts. His business goal is to expand his business within five years. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy motorcycle spare parts.

loans.name: Zakia

texts.en:
Zakai is a 40-year-old single woman. She has three children with ages ranging from 3 years to 17 years. She describes herself to be honest, cheerful, and determined. She operates a food service where she sells food to customers. She has been involved in this business for four years. Her business is located in a viable place and her primary customers are local people in the town. She describes her biggest business challenge to be unstable high market prices.

She will use the Kes 50,000 loan to buy food ingredients to prepare meals to sell. She plans to expand her business in the next five years. Her business goal is to employ new staff and open a new similar food stall within five years. She is a determined woman, focused and very optimistic.

loans.use: to buy food ingredients to prepare meals to sell.

loans.name: Elina

texts.en:
Elina is a resident of Malindi, Kenya. She is a single mother of two children. She owns a school which has been in operation for three years. She began the school from her personal savings. She also owns a boutique, selling used clothes.

Elina is applying for a loan of 15,900 Kenya shillings to purchase desks and chairs, school uniforms and other teaching aids. She believes that she has seen progress  so far and will be able to establish a fully fledged primary school in the near future. Her only challenge is some students not paying the fees on time. The additional income from this loan will help Elina pay for her children’s education.

loans.use: To purchase desks and chairs, school uniforms and other teaching aids.

loans.name: Lameck Otieno

texts.en:
Lameck is the first motorcycle owner to register in the community health support programme(CHWSP) in Kisumu county Kenya. Lameck is married and is a member of youth group in Kisumu who want to make a difference in their community. Lameck leads a group of young people who would like to contribute in the welfare of their community in Kisumu. Lameck will be providing transport to selected Community Health Workers who will be conducting visitation in their community, and additionally he will support youth training camps where community awareness on health and hygiene will be discussed. 

By supporting the Community Health Workers in Kisumu, Lameck will be contributing immensely towards easing transportation and coverage of CHWs in Kisumu Town. Lameck will be attached to a CHW in Kisumu County and four times in a month will be providing transport to CHWs on their regular visitation of patients or providing health education to the community. Lameck will also be on standby in his community wherever transport is needed to transport patients in the nearby clinic. The motorcycle will also assist in supporting Lameck young family, during other days as he will use the bike as taxi transporting people and produce to the market.

Lameck vision is to create the largest BodAfya network in Kenya involving youth engaged in motorcycle taxis and Community Health Workers in Kisumu County.

loans.use: To buy a Motorcycle for Community Health Work and Livelihood Support

loans.name: Joseph Owour

texts.en:
Joseph is the second motorcycle owner to register in the community health support programme. (CHWSP) in Kisumu county Kenya. Joseph is married and is a member of youth group on Kisumu who want to make a difference in their community. He is also the co chair of a group of young people who would like to contribute in the welfare of their community in Kisumu.  Joseph will be providing transport to selected Community Health Workers who will be conducting visitation in their community, and additionally he will participate and support youth training camps where community awareness on health and hygiene will be discussed Kisumu Town. 

By supporting the Community Health Workers in Kisumu, Joseph will be contributing immensely towards easing transportation and coverage of CHWs in Kisumu Town. Lameck will be attached to a CHW in Kisumu County and four times in a month will be providing transport to CHWs on their regular visitation of patients or providing health education to the community. Joseph will also be on standby in his community wherever transport is needed to transport patients in the nearby clinic. The motorcycle will also assist in supporting Joseph direct family and siblings during other days as he will use the bike as taxi transporting people and produce to the market.

Joseph is engaged in recruiting more motorcycle taxi drivers in the CHW support programme in Kisumu County.

loans.use: To buy a Motorcycle to Support Community Health Work and Livelihoods.

loans.name: Juliety  Mkhambe

texts.en:
Juliety is among the many women who are joining in the CHW programme. Juliety is a mother of three and lives in coast province of Kenya in Mombasa County. As a mother Juliety has been concerned with the plight of mothers and children and she would like to contribute in supporting CHWs targeting issues pertaining to mothers and children in Mombassa County. 

Julliety has already identified a CHW enrolled in  Ministry of Health in her community. Juliety will support the CHW by providing transport four times in a month, while the CHW undertakes the normal family and patients visitations 

Juliety would like to support young girls and mothers to get good advice on bringing up healthy children and taking appropriate health options to plan for their family. Juliety belongs to a women groups who support each other in advancing better health and livelihoods for their families.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle to support Community Health Work and Livelihoods

loans.name: Paulo Okurutu

texts.en:
Paulo was born in 1977 in Sakaru village in Bungoma County; Paulo is married with children and is engaged in retail small scale business. Paulo has been engaged in motorcycle business for the last three years on a rented motorcycle. Paulo is excited to own his own motorcycle and would like to make a difference in his community by supporting the community health work.

Paulo will support  the CHW undertake his normal routine once a week by providing transportation in Bungoma Town and its outskirts in making visits to patients, and attending medical camps. Paulo will also be linked with activities targeting the youth and combating domestic violence. 

Paulo will also use the income generated from his motorcycle taxi business to support his family. He hopes to become a CHW volunteer in his community once he has finished paying for his bike.

loans.use: To buy Motorcycle for Community Health Work and Livelihoods

loans.name: Silas     Odhiambo

texts.en:
Silas lives in Kisumu and his married, he has been involved in Motorcycle Taxi Business for two years. Silas wants to own a motorcycle and has been linked with Community Health Worker in his community. He will support the community health worker by providing transport on set days, this will give the needed capacity to the CHW to be able to reach many more families during counseling appointments and health visitation.

Silas will also use the income generated from his motorcycle taxi business to support his family. He hopes to become a CHW volunteer in his community once he has finished paying for his bike.

loans.use: To buy a Motorcycle for Community Health Work and Livelihoods

loans.name: Elias  Odour

texts.en:
Elias was born in Kamudiwo Village in Siaya County, he is currently living with his familyand children in  Kisumu. Elias has been involved in Motorcycle Taxi Business on rented motorcycle for two years, he wants to own a motorcycle and support the community health work in his community.
